intro: Ulmus campestris gracilis, commonly known as the narrow-leaved elm, is a deciduous tree native to parts of Europe and western Asia. It is characterized by its slender, elongated leaves that are typically 5–10 cm in length. The tree has a straight, often single trunk with a spreading crown, and its bark is smooth and grayish in color. It prefers well-drained soils and is often found in open woodlands or along riverbanks. Due to its ornamental value, it is occasionally cultivated in gardens and parks.
